indexes/cryptography/pkcs/pkcs-7.html.title: PKCS 7
indexes/cryptography/pkcs/pkcs-7.html.description:
In this standard, padding is done in whole bytes. The value of each added byte is the number of bytes that are added, i.e. bytes, each of value are added. The number of bytes added will depend on the block boundary to which the message needs to be extended.01
02 02
03 03 03
04 04 04 04
05 05 05 05 05
06 06 06 06 06 06
07 07 07 07 07 07 07
This padding method is possible if and only if is less than 256 bytes.Example
The block size is 8 bytes and padding is required for 4 bytes
... | A1 A1 A1 A1 A1 A1 A1 A1 | A1 A1 A1 A1 04 04 04 04 | If the length of the original data is an integer multiple of the block size , then an extra block of bytes with value is added. This is necessary so the deciphering algorithm can determine with certainty whether the last byte of the last block is a pad byte indicating the number of padding bytes added or part of the plaintext message.Consider a plaintext message whose bytes are multiple of with the last byte of plaintext being . With no additional information, the deciphering algorithm will not be able to determine whether the last byte is a plaintext byte or a pad byte. By adding bytes each of value after the plaintext byte, the deciphering algorithm can always treat the last byte as a pad byte and strip the appropriate number of pad bytes off the end of the ciphertext; said number of bytes to be stripped based on the value of the last byte.... | 04 03 02 01 | 04 03 02 01 | # This is Wrong!
... | 04 03 02 01 | 04 03 02 01 | 04 04 04 04 | # This is Nice!
The maximum block size is 255, as it is the biggest number a byte can contain.

headers.heading: Padding

indexes/cryptography/cbc-cyber-block-cha.title: CBC - Cyber-Block Chaining
indexes/cryptography/cbc-cyber-block-cha.description:
This is what ensures that no two blocks (even if they contain identical plaintext) will encrypt to the same ciphertext. It does this by mixing the ciphertext from the previous round into the plaintext of the next round using the XOR operator. In mathematical notation: Let = the plaintext, and = the plaintext of block . Let = the corresponding ciphertext, and = the ciphertext of block . Let = the number of blocks ( and have the same number of blocks by definition). Let = the initialization vector - a random string - frequently (incorrectly) set to all zeroes. Let = a single-block encryption operation (any block encryption algorithm, such as AES or DES, it doesn't matter which), with some unique and unknown (to the attacker) secret key (that we don't notate here). Let = the corresponding decryption operation. We can define the encrypted ciphertexct -- in terms of the encryption algorithm, the plaintext, and the initialization vector:Decryption is the opposite:

Once all blocks are decrypted, the Padding on the last block is validated.

indexes/cryptography/padding.html.title: Padding
indexes/cryptography/padding.html.description: In cryptography, padding is the practice of adding data to the beginning, middle, or end of a message prior to encryption.

indexes/cryptography/padding-oracle-&-us.title: Padding Oracle & Usage
indexes/cryptography/padding-oracle-&-us.description:
A padding oracle is a specific type of oracle that will take encrypted data from the user, attempt to decrypt it privately, and then reveal whether or not the Padding is correct.Frequently, a server will entrust a client with encrypted data in either a http header, cookie, etc. The advantage by doing thisd is that the server doesnt need to mainain the state of the client's session, the client itself holds the state. The disadvantage: if the client can find a way to modify the encrypted data, it can play with private state informationA block cipher operates on data in fixed-size blocks (128-bit for AES). It encrypts each block and moves onto the next one, and so on. When the data is decrypted, it also starts with the first block and so on. What happens if the length of the data isn't a multiple of the block size? What happens if more than one block is identical, and therefore encrypts identically?
Most block ciphers uses PKCS #7 for padding. See CBC - Cyber-Block Chaining.
XOR is a bitwise operator used in cryptography to mix two values together in a reversible way. A plaintext XORed witha key creates ciphertext, and XORing it again with the same key returns the original plaintext The attacker breaks the ciphertext into the individual blocks, based on the blocksize of the encryption algorithm. We're going to decrypt each block separately, this can be done in any order, but it makes more sense to start with and go on through . The attacker generates his own block of ciphertext. It doesn't matter what it decrypts to or what the value is. Typically he starts with all zeroes, but any random text will work fine. This block is denoted as . The attacker creates the string and sends it to the oracle for decryption. The oracle attempts to decrypt the string as follows: = our custom-generated ciphertext block. = the byte of our custom-generated ciphertext block. = the plaintext generated by decrypting our string, . = the block of . = byte of the plaintext block. = the number of bytes in each block. The variables marked with prime ' are ones that result from our custom equation, and variables without a prime are ones from the original equation. We can define in terms of our custom ciphertext, the , and the decryption function:P′1 = D(C′) ⊕ IV P′2 = D(C_N) ⊕ C′ These are the two blocks we created being decrypted in the usual way: . is meaningless garbage, it doesn't matter what it decrypts, but ...Given: Knowing: Implies So now we know that , so we can reduce the formula to:Now we have four values in our equation: : An unknown value that the server calculates. : An unknown value that we want to determine, from the original text : A known value from the original ciphertext. : A value that we control, and can change at will. But we can't solve the last formula cause we don't know values nor , can we? We have one more piece of information, the padding oracle, that means that we can determine when (the last byte of ) is equal to "". We can determine when has a valid padding! .With the previous formula, we will look at the last character of the encrypted strings:Heart of the Attack We send to the oracle with every possible value of , until we find a value that doesn't generate a padding error. When we find that value, we will know that the value at is "". Otherwise, the padding would be wrong. Except if.... At this point we have variables: : The valid padding value "". : UNKNOWN. The last byte of plaintext. : The last byte of the previous block of ciphertext. : The byte we control to create the valid padding.
Now let's re-make the equation, since XOR is commutative, we can swap the variables: Original: Swapped: Substitute with 1: And now we got the last byte of plaintext.So we know the value of the last byte of

indexes/cs/boolean-algebra/expressions/x.title: XOR
indexes/cs/boolean-algebra/expressions/x.description: Shorthand for "exclusive or", is often denoted as  ‘’ or sometimes denoted as ‘^’ in some programming languages: returns 1 when its two variables have opposing values and 0 otherwise.We write to denote the bitwise XOR of two strings, this expression is generally not defined when the strings are different lengths, but in rare occasions it is useful to consider the shorter string being padded with 0s, when this is the case, we must have an explicit convention about whether the shorter string is padded with leading 0s or trailing 0s. Xoring a string with itself results in zeroes. Xoring with zeroes has no effect. Xoring with one flips every bit. Xor is symmetric. Xor is Associative. XORing a bit with has no effect, while XORing with flips that bit, you can think of as: "starting with , flip the bits at all the positions where has a ." So if is all 's, then gives the bitwise complement of . If then means "the result of flipping every other bit in ."

indexes/networking/application-layer/dns.title: DNS
indexes/networking/application-layer/dns.description:
Def The Domain Name System is: A distributed database implemented in a hierarchy of DNS servers. An Application layer Protocol that allows hosts to query the distributed database.
DNS is commonly employed by other application-layer protocols like HTTP to translate user-supplied hostnames to IP addresses .The DNS protocol runs over UDP and uses port 53.But DNS provides a few other important services in addition to translating hostnames to IP addresses: A host with a complicated hostname can have one or more alias names. For example, a hostname such as relay1.west-coast.enterprise.com could have, say, two aliases such as enterprise.com and www.enterprise.com. In this case, the first hostname is said to be a canonical hostname. DNS can be invoked to obtain the canonical hostname for a supplied alias hostname as well as the IP address of the host. The hostname of the Yahoo mail server is more complicated than simply yahoo.com (the canonical hostname might be something like relay1.west-coast.yahoo.com). DNS is invoked to solve the simpler hostnames in email addresses
DNS is also used to perform load distribution among replicated servers, such as replicated Web Servers. Busy sites like chatgpt.com are replicated over multiple servers, with each server running on a different End System and each having a different IP address. For replicates servers, a set of IP addresses is thus associated with one alias hostname, when a client requests for the hostname, the server responds with the entire set of IP addresses, but rotates the ordering of the addresses within each reply, this distributes the traffic among the replicated servers. DNS uses a laaarge number of servers, organized in a hierarchical fashion and distributed around the world. No single DNS server has all of the mappings for all of the hosts in the Internet. Instead, the mappings are distributed across the DNS servers.There are 3 classes of DNS servers, but before that i'll explain ho these three clases of servers interact. Suppose a DNS clients wants to determine the IP address for the hostname www.amazon.com: The client first contacts one of the root servers, which returns IP addresses for TLD servers for the top-level domain .com The client then contacts one of these TDL servers, which returns the IP address of an authoritative server for amazon.com Finally the client contacts one of the authoritative servers for amazon.com.
These provide the IP addresses of the TLD servers. With more than 1,000 root servers over the world, these servers are copies of 13 different root servers, managed by 12 different organizations, and coordinated through the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA).TLD servers provide the IP addresses for authoritative DNS servers. For each of the top-level domains (such as com, org, gov, mx, uk) there is a TLD server (or server cluster).Every accessible host (web or mail servers) on the Internet must provide publicly accessible DNS records that map the names of those hosts to IP addresses. An organization’s authoritative DNS server houses these DNS records. An organization can implement its own authoritative DNS server or it can pay to have these records stored in an authoritative server of some service provider.
Each ISP has a local DNS server (also called default name server). When a host connects to an ISP, t he ISP provides the host with the IP addresses of one or more of its local DNS servers. A host’s local DNS server is typically “close to” the host. When a host makes a DNS query, the query is sent to the local DNS server, which acts a proxy, forwarding the query into the DNS server hierarchy.
Host cse.nyu.edu sends a DNS query message to its local DNS server dns.nyu.edu, the query contains the hostname to be translated, namely gaia.cs.umass.edu Local DNS server forwards the query to a root DNS server. Root server takes note of the .edu suffix and returns to the local DNS server a list of IP addresses for TLD servers responsible for edu Local DNS resends the query message to one of these TLD servers. TLD server takes note of the umass.edu suffix and responds with the IP address of the authoritative DNS server of the requested hostname, namely dns.umass.edu. Local DNS resends query directly to dns.umass.edu. Authoritative server responds with the IP address of gaia.cs.umass.edu Local DNS finally returns the IP address of gaia.cs.umass.edu to the requesting host. When a DNS server receives a DNS reply (a mapping from a hostname to an IP address), it can cache the mapping in its local memory. If a hostname/IP address pair is cached in a DNS server and another query arrives to the DNS server for the same hostname, the DNS server can provide the desired IP address, even if it is not authoritative for the hostname. DNS servers discard cached information after a period of time (often set to two days).A local DNS server also caches the IP addresses of TLD servers, bypassing the root DNS servers in a query chain. Root server are almost always bypassed.This way DNS exploits DNS caching in order to improve the delay performance and to reduce the number of DNS messages ricocheting around the Internet.DNS servers store resource records (RRs), including RRs that provide hostname-to-IP mappings. Each DNS reply message carries one or more resource recordsAn RR is a four-tuple that contains the following fields:Name, Value, Type, TTL TTL is the time to live of the resource record; it determines when a resource should be removed from a cache. The meaning of Name and Value depend on Type: If Type=A, then Name is a hostname and Value is the IP address for the hostname. Thus, a Type A record provides the standard hostname-to-IP address mapping. (relay1.bar.foo.com, 145.37.93.126, A) is a Type A record. Even if a DNS server is not authoritative (suppose a TLD server), it may contain a Type A record in its cache pointing to an authoritative one.) If Type=NS, then Name is a domain (foo.com) and Value is the hostname of an authoritative DNS server able to obtain the IP addresses for hosts in the domain. This record is used to route DNS queries further along in the query chain. (foo.com, dns.foo.com, NS) is a Type NS record If Type=CNAME, then Value is a canonical hostname for the alias hostname Name . This record can provide querying hosts the canonical name for a hostname. (foo.com, relay1.bar.foo.com, CNAME) is a CNAME record. If Type=MX, then Value is the canonical name of a mail server that has an alias hostname Name. As an example, (foo.com, mail.bar.foo.com, MX) is an MX record. MX records allow the hostnames of mail servers to have simple aliases. To obtain the canonical name for the mail server, a DNS client would query for an MX record; to obtain the canonical name for another server, the DNS client would query for the CNAME record. Both DNS query and DNS reply messages have the same format: The first 12 bytes is the header section. The first field is a 2-bytes number that identifies the query allowing the client to match received replies with sent queries. There are a number of flags in the flag field. A 1-bit flag indicates whether the message is a query (0) or a reply (1). A 1-bit authoritative flag is set in a reply message when a DNS server is an authoritative server for a queried name. A 1-bit recursion-desired flag is set when a client (host or DNS server) desires that the DNS server perform recursion when it doesn’t have the record. A 1-bit recursion-available field is set in a reply if the DNS server supports recursion. In the header, there are also four number-of fields. These fields indicate the number of occurrences of the four types of data sections that follow the header. A question section contains information about the query, it includes (1) a name field that contains the name that is being queried, and (2) a type field that indicates the type of question being asked about the name - for example, a host address associated with a name (Type A). Answer section contains the resource records for the name that was originally queried. A reply can return multiple RRs in the answer, since a hostname can have multiple IP addresses (like for replicated servers). Authority section contains records of other authoritative servers. Additional section contains other helpful records.
A registrar is a commercial entity that verifies the uniqueness of the domain name and enters the domain name into the DNS database. When you register a domain name with some register, you also need to provide the registrar with the names and IP addresses of your primary and secondary authoritative DNS servers.For each authoritative DNS server, the registrar would then make sure that a Type NS and a Type A record are entered into the TLD server, so you or the registrar would insert the following two RRs into the DNS system:(canekzamudio.com, dns1.canekzamudio.com, NS) (dns1.canekzamudio.com, 185.199.111.153, A) You'll also have to make sure that the Type A RR for your web server is entered into your authoritative DNS server. An UPDATE option of DNS protocol allows data to be dynamically added or deleted from the database via DNS messages.

indexes/networking/application-layer/htt.title: HTTP
indexes/networking/application-layer/htt.description:
Definition The HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP), it is implemented in two programs: a client program and a server program, talking to each other by exchanging HTTP messages. HTTP defines the structure of these messages and how the client and server exchange the messages.
HTTP uses TCP as its underlying transport protocol. The HTTP client first initiates a TCP connection with the server, once the connection is established, the browser and the server processes access TCP through their Socket interfaces.Stateless Protocol HTTP is said to be a stateless protocol, this means that the server sends requested files to clients without storing any state information about the client. GET /somedir/page.html HTTP/1.1 /* Request line */ Host: ww.someschool.edu /* Connection: close Header Lines User-agent: Mozilla/5.0 Accept-language: fr */ The first line of a request is called the request line, it has three fields: Method fields GET - Used when the browser requests an object, with the requested object identified in the URL field POST - Sends data to the server, usually to create, update or answer something PUT - It allows a user to upload or replace an object to a specific path on a Web server. DELETE - Removes an object from the server. PATCH - Updates part of a resource. HEAD - Works like GET but only retrieves headers, not the full content. It's handy for checking metadata without downloading the full response. OPTIONS - Tells you what methods are available for a specific resource. TRACE - Similar to OPTIONS it shows which methods are allowed. CONNECT - Used to create a secure connection, like for HTPPS.
URL field HTTP version field Host: - Specifies the host on which the object resides
Connection: - A close connection tells the server to use Non-Persistent Connection. User-agent: - This specifies the browser type that is making the request to the server. Accept-language: - Indicates the preferred client's language.
Used with POST or related methods, the entity body contains what the user entered into the form fields. Unused in many other methods.HTTP/1.1 200 OK // Initial status line Connection: close /* Date: Tue, 18 Aug 2015 15:44:04 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.3 (CentOS) Last-Modified: Tue, 18 Aug 2015 15:11:03 GMT Header lines Content-Length: 6821 Content-Type: text/html */ (data data data data data ...) // Entity body Protocol version field Status code & Status message 200 OK - Request succeeded and information returned in response. 301 Moved Permanently - Requested object has been moved, the new URL is specified in the Location header of the response. Client software often follow automatically the new URL. 400 Bad Request - Generic error indicating that the request could not be understood by the server. 404 Not Found - The requested resource doesn't exist on the server. Response headers.It contains the requested object

indexes/networking/transport-layer/tcp.h.title: TCP
indexes/networking/transport-layer/tcp.h.description:
The TCP service model includes a connection-oriented service and a Reliable data transfer service. When an application invokes TCP as its transport Protocol, the application receives both of these services from TCP.
TCP has the Client and Server exchange transport-layer control information with each other before the application-level messages begin to flow. This so-called handshaking procedure alerts the client and server, allowing them to prepare for an onslaught of packets. After the handshaking phase, a TCP connection is said to exist between the Sockets of the two processes. The connection is a full-duplex connection in that the two processes can send messages to each other over the connection at the same time. When the application finishes sending messages, it must tear down the connection.The communicating processes can rely on TCP to deliver all data sent without error and in the proper order. When one side of the application passes a stream of bytes into a socket, it can count on TCP to deliver the same stream of bytes to the receiving socket, with no missing or duplicate bytes.
TCP also includes a congestion-control mechanism, a service for the general welfare of the Internet rather than for the direct benefit of the communicating processes. The TCP congestion-control mechanism throttles a sending process (client or server) when the network is congested between sender and receiver. TCP congestion control also attempts to limit each TCP connection to its fair share of network bandwidth.
Transport Layer Security (TLS) TCP-enhanced-with-TLS provides critical process-to-process security services, including encryption, data integrity, and end-point authentication. TLS is not a third Internet transport protocol, but instead is an enhancement of TCP, with the enhancements being implemented in the application layer. In particular, if an application wants to use the services of TLS, it needs to include TLS code (existing, highly optimized libraries and classes) in both the client and server sides of the application. TLS has its own socket API that is similar to the traditional TCP socket API. When an application uses TLS, the sending process passes cleartext data to the TLS socket; TLS in the sending host then encrypts the data and passes the encrypted data to the TCP socket. The encrypted data travels over the Internet to the TCP socket in the receiving process. The receiving socket passes the encrypted data to TLS, which decrypts the data. Finally, TLS passes the cleartext data through its TLS socket to the receiving process.

indexes/networking/transport-layer/udp.h.title: UDP
indexes/networking/transport-layer/udp.h.description: UDP is no-frills, lightweight transport protocol, providing minimal services. UDP is connectionless, so there is no handshaking before the two processes start to communicate. UDP provides an unreliable data transfer service—that is, when a process sends a message into a UDP socket, UDP provides no guarantee that the message will ever reach the receiving process. Furthermore, messages that do arrive at the receiving process may arrive out of order.UDP does not include a congestion-control mechanism, so the sending side of UDP can pump data into the layer below (the network layer) at any rate it pleases.

indexes/networking/ip-address.html.title: IP address
indexes/networking/ip-address.html.description:
#Networking
It's a unique identifier for other hosts to communicate with an specific machine. When using the TCP-IP protocol suite, we need to assign an IP address for each device connected to the network, we have IPv4 and IPv6.
An IP address comprises four octets, i.e., 32 bits. Being 8 bits, an octet allows us to represent a decimal number between 0 and 255. At the risk of oversimplifying things, the 0 and 255 are reserved for the network and broadcast addresses, respectively. In other words, 192.168.1.0 is the network address, while 192.168.1.255 is the broadcast address. Sending to the broadcast address targets all the hosts on the network.A private address is an IP address used within a private network, such as home, office, or enterprise environment. These addresses are not routable on the public internet, meaning they are used only for internal communication between devices on the same network. Defines the following three ranges of private IP addresses: 10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255 (10/8) 172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255 (172.16/12) 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255 (192.168/16)

indexes/networking/protocol.html.title: Protocol
indexes/networking/protocol.html.description: A protocol defines the format and the order of messages exchanged between two or more communicating entities, as well as the actions taken on the transmission and/or receipt of a message or other event.The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the Internet Protocol (IP) are two of the most important protocols in the Internet. The IP protocol specifies the format of the packets that are sent and received among routers and End Systems. The Internet’s principal protocols are collectively known as TCP/IP.

indexes/networking/tcp-ip.html.title: TCP-IP
indexes/networking/tcp-ip.html.description:
Tags: #Networking
Implemented model of OSI model, TCP/IP stands for Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol, one of the strengths of this model is that it allows a network to continue to function as parts of it are out of service. It is also called as Protocol Stack Each layer provides its service by (1) performing certain actions within that layer and by (2) using the services of the layer directly below it. The application layer is where network applications and their application-layer protocols reside. This includes many protocols, such as the HTTP protocol, SMTP, FTP, etc.
We’ll see that certain network functions, such as the translation of human-friendly names for Internet end systems like www.ietf.org to a 32-bit network address, are also done with the help of a specific application-layer protocol, namely, the domain name system (DNS)An application-layer protocol is distributed over multiple end systems, with the application in one end system using the protocol to exchange packets of information with the application in another end system. We’ll refer to this packet of information at the application layer as a message.This layer transports application-layer messages between application endpoints. In the internet, there are two transport protocols: TCP and UDP, either of which can transport application-layer messagesTCP provides a connection-oriented service to its applications. This service includes guaranteed delivery of application-layer messages to the destination and flow control (that is, sender/receiver speed matching). TCP also breaks long messages into shorter segments and provides a congestion-control mechanism, so that a source throttles its transmission rate when the network is congested.UDP protocol provides a connectionless service to its applications. This is a no-frills service that provides no reliability, no flow control, and no congestion control. In this book, we’ll refer to a transport-layer packet as a segment.The Internet’s network layer is responsible for moving network-layer packets known as datagrams from one host to another. The Internet transport-layer protocol (TCP or UDP) in a source host passes a transport-layer segment and a destination address to the network layer, just as you would give the postal service a letter with a destination address. The network layer then provides the service of delivering the segment to the transport layer in the destination host.The Internet’s network layer includes the celebrated IP protocol, which defines the fields in the datagram as well as how the end systems and routers act on these fields. There is only one IP protocol, and all Internet components that have a network layer must run the IP protocol. The Internet’s network layer also contains routing protocols that determine the routes that datagrams take between sources and destinations.
The Internet’s network layer routes a datagram through a series of routers between the source and destination. To move a packet from one node (host or router) to the next node in the route, the network layer relies on the services of the link layer. In particular, at each node, the network layer passes the datagram down to the link layer, which delivers the datagram to the next node along the route. At this next node, the link layer passes the datagram up to the network layerThe services provided by the link layer depend on the specific link-layer protocol that is employed over the link.As datagrams typically need to traverse several links to travel from source to destination, a datagram may be handled by different link-layer protocols at different links along its route.The network layer will receive a different service from each of the different link-layer protocols. In this book, we’ll refer to the link-layer packets as frames.While the job of the link layer is to move entire frames from one network element to an adjacent network element, the job of the physical layer is to move the individual bits within the frame from one node to the next.The protocols in this layer are again link dependent and further depend on the actual transmission medium of the link (for example, twisted-pair copper wire, single-mode fiber optics). For example, Ethernet has many physical-layer protocols: one for twisted-pair copper wire, another for coaxial cable, another for fiber, and so on. In each case, a bit is moved across the link in a different way.

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
